relevantProvisions.title: Effect of Listing
relevantProvisions.applicationToScenario: This provision directly applies to the scenario because two potential suppliers appear on a list of contractors proposed for debarment due to alleged fraudulent practices. According to FAR 9.405, contractors proposed for debarment are excluded from receiving contracts, and agencies shall not solicit offers from or award contracts to these suppliers unless there is a compelling reason determined by the agency head.

relevantProvisions.title: Total Small Business Set-Asides
relevantProvisions.applicationToScenario: With an estimated value of $145,000, this procurement exceeds the micro-purchase threshold but is below the simplified acquisition threshold. Given that market research indicates at least five small businesses can provide the equipment at competitive prices, this procurement should be set aside exclusively for small businesses. This addresses the agency's previous citation for non-compliance with small business utilization requirements.

relevantProvisions.title: Sustainable Acquisition Policy
relevantProvisions.applicationToScenario: This provision applies because the agency has a sustainability initiative requiring consideration of energy efficiency and environmental impact. FAR 23.103 mandates that 95% of new contract actions require products to be energy-efficient. The scenario specifically notes that computers and printers should be ENERGY STAR certified, which aligns with the ENERGY STAR designation requirement in this FAR provision.

complianceIssues.issueDescription: The Purchasing Manager has an undisclosed conflict of interest with a key supplier owned by his brother-in-law and personally handles all negotiations with this supplier.
complianceIssues.regulationViolated: Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (42 U.S.C. ยง 1320a-7b(b))
complianceIssues.correctiveAction: Implement a formal conflict of interest policy requiring all employees to disclose family or financial relationships with suppliers. Remove the Purchasing Manager from negotiations with the brother-in-law's company and assign an independent team to evaluate this supplier relationship. Conduct an audit of past transactions with this supplier to ensure pricing and terms were competitive and appropriate.

complianceIssues.issueDescription: MedTech lacks formal supplier qualification processes and does not verify required certifications, licenses, or check suppliers against government exclusion lists.
complianceIssues.correctiveAction: Establish a documented supplier qualification procedure that includes verification of certifications, licenses, and compliance with quality standards. Implement a system to regularly check suppliers against government exclusion lists. Create a supplier audit program to verify compliance with requirements. Develop a supplier rating system based on quality, delivery, and compliance metrics.

complianceIssues.issueDescription: Purchase orders lack detailed specifications, quality requirements are communicated verbally, and changes are made without updating documentation. Records are only kept for one year.
complianceIssues.correctiveAction: Revise purchase order templates to include detailed specifications and quality requirements. Implement a formal change control process requiring written documentation of all purchase order changes. Extend record retention to at least five years or the lifetime of the device. Provide training to all purchasing staff on proper documentation practices and regulatory requirements.

scenarioDecisions.correctAction: Do not proceed with this supplier until proper verification of compliance is obtained. Request on-site audit or third-party verification of the supplier's certifications. Contact the certification body directly to verify the supplier's status. Consider alternative suppliers with verified certifications even if at higher cost. If timeline is critical, split the order between verified suppliers while continuing due diligence.

applicableRegulations: OECD Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains
scenarioDecisions.correctAction: Require the supplier to complete the Conflict Minerals Reporting Template (CMRT) with full supply chain documentation. Verify the supplier conducts appropriate due diligence on their sources. Implement a contract clause requiring ongoing compliance and documentation. Consider third-party verification of the supplier's conflict minerals program. Ensure your company's SEC filings accurately reflect the current state of due diligence.

Request updated Safety Data Sheets that comply with current GHS format requirements. Do not purchase materials until compliant documentation is received. Verify the supplier's TSCA compliance status through EPA's Chemical Data Reporting database. Consider alternative suppliers who maintain current documentation. Implement a procedure to verify SDS currency and compliance before all hazardous material purchases.

applicableRegulations: FAR 52.219-8 Utilization of Small Business Concerns
scenarioDecisions.correctAction: Award the subcontract to the qualified small business to meet federal contract small business utilization requirements. Develop a transition plan to mitigate risks associated with the small business's limited experience. Provide additional oversight during initial work phases. Document the decision to support small business utilization in contract compliance reporting. Consider mentoring the small business to build capacity for future contracts.
